title: Bulgaria racism scandal deepens amid suspicion stadium stewards among perpetrators
text:
The scandal over the monkey chants and Nazi salutes aimed at England’s black players during their win in Bulgaria has deepened amid suspicions stadium staff had been among the perpetrators.

Independent observers employed to monitor Monday night’s European Championship qualifier in Sofia witnessed around 20 people removing official-looking bibs before joining home fans in racially abusing the likes of Raheem Sterling, Marcus Rashford and Tyrone Mings.

Uefa’s anti-discrimination monitoring partner, Fare, confirmed that the observers had seen, but not videoed, bibs being removed, claiming it was “quite common” for clubs and national associations in Eastern Europe to employ known hooligans in roles such as stadium security.

“We can speculate that people among them were actually working in security, which would be extreme negligence on behalf of the Bulgarian Football Union,” Pavel Klymenko, Fare’s Eastern Europe Development Officer, told The Daily Telegraph.

Klymenko said that even if the individuals in question were merely disguised as stadium staff – perhaps in order to sneak into the ground undetected – the BFU was still to blame for “insufficient checks” at the gates.
